problem.tex: Let $\Omega$ be a region containing the closed unit disc $\overline D$ and suppose $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ is holomorphic and satisfies $|f(z)|\leq1$ for all $z\in\overline D$. Suppose also that $f(0)=0$. Then $|f(z)|\leq|z|$ for all $z\in\overline D$, $|f'(0)|\leq1$, and if equality holds in either case then $f(z)=\lambda z$ for some constant $\lambda$.

solution.tex: Consider the function $g(z)=\frac{f(z)}{z}$. By assumption, $0$ is a root of $f$ which means $g$ is holomorphic. The maximum modulus principle means that the maximum of $g$ occurs on its boundary. On the boundary $|z|=1$, \[|g(z)|=\left|\frac{f(z)}{z}\right|=|f(z)|\leq1.\] Thus for all $z\in\overline D$\[|g(z)|\leq1\]If $z\neq0$ then multiplying by $|z|$ gives \[|f(z)|\leq|z|.\] At $z=0$, $g(0)=f'(0)$ by definition of the difference quotient. Thus $|f'(0)|\leq1$. If equality holds in either case then $g$ is constant by the maximum modulus principle. That shows the result.
